class.name: Time
class.brief: Time represent a point in Time
class.doc:
Time represent a point in Time. Why re-implementing one of this object and not using a `struct timeval` or a `std::chrono`. We are dealing with long living experiment on heterogenous system. Under this circunstances, we would like also to measure precise time difference. For this purpose we could use the framegrabber monolotic clock, which is timestamping every frame we acquired.
Well the issue is that we cannot solely rely on this clock, as we may have several computers each with their own monolithic clock. Or even with a single computer, every time we started the tracking we must assume a new monotonic clock.
We could use the wall clock but this clock may be resetted any time, and we would end up with issue where a time difference between two consecutive frame could be negative.
Inspired from golang [time.Time](https://golang.org/pkg/time#Time) we propose an Object that store both a Wall time, and a Monotonic timestamp. But here we could have different monotonic timestamp. We try, whenever its possible (both Time and Time have a monotonic time, and they are issued from the same monotonic clock), use that value for Time difference and Comparison. Otherwise the Wall clock value will be used with the issue regarding the jitter or Wall clock reset.
Differentiaing Monotonic clock is done through MonoclockID values. The 0 value is reserved for the SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK and which is used by Now. When reading saved monotonic Timestamp from the filesystem (as it is the case when reading data from different <TrackingDataDirectory> ), care must be taken to assign different MonoclockID for each of those reading. This class does not enforce any mechanism. The only entry point to define the MonoclockID is through the utility function FromTimestampAndMonotonic.
Every time are considered UTC.

variable.name: SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK
variable.brief: The fort::myrmidon::Time::MonoclockID reserved for the current system

class.name: Overflow
class.brief: Time values can overflow when performing operation on them.

typedef.name: ConstPtr
typedef.brief: A const pointer to a Time

typedef.name: SortableKey
typedef.brief: An object optimized for std::map or std::set
typedef.doc: SortableKey is an object constructed from current fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to be used as a computationnaly efficient key in std::map or std::set. please note that this key has lost any monotonic information.

method.name: Add
method.brief: Adds a Duration to a Time

method.name: After
method.brief: Reports if this time is after t

argument.name: t
argument.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to test against

method.name: Before
method.brief: Reports if this time is before t

argument.name: t
argument.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to test against

method.name: Equals
method.brief: Reports if this time is the same than t

argument.name: t
argument.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to test against

method.name: FromTimestamp
method.brief: Creates a Time from a protobuf Timestamp
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time from a protobuf Timestamp. The fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: FromTimestampAndMonotonic
method.brief: Creates a Time from a protobuf Timestamp and an external Monotonic clock
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time from a protobuf Timestamp and an external monotonic clock. The two values should correspond to the same physical time. It is an helper function to create accurate fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time from data saved in `fort.hermes.FrameReadout` protobuf messages that saves both a Wall time value and a framegrabber timestamp for each frame. It is the caller responsability to manage monoID value for not mixing timestamp issued from different clocks. Nothing prevent you to use fort::myrmidon::Time::SYSTEM_MONOTONIC_CLOCK for the monoID value but the behavior manipulating resulting time is undefined.

argument.name: nsecs
argument.doc: the external monotonic value in nanoseconds

method.name: FromTimeT
method.brief: Creates a Time from `time_t`
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time from `time_t`. The fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: FromTimeval
method.brief: Creates a Time from `struct timeval`
method.doc: Creates a fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time from `struct timeval`. The fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time will not have any monotonic clock value.

method.name: HasMono
method.brief: Reports the presence of a monotonic time value
method.doc: Reports the presence of a monotonic time value. Only fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time issued by fort::myrmidon::Time::Now or fort::myrmidon::Time::FromTimestampAndMonotonic contains a monotonic time value.

method.name: MonoFromSecNSec
method.brief: Helpers to convert (sec,nsec) to nsec
method.doc: Helpers to convert (sec,nsec) to nsec. Throws fort::myrmidon::Time::Overflow on overflow.

method.name: MonoID
method.brief: Returns the referred MonoclockID.
method.doc: Returns the referred fort::myrmidon::Time::MonoclockID. It throws std::exception if this fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time has no monotonic clock value (see fort::myrmidon::Time::HasMono).

method.name: MonotonicValue
method.brief: Returns the monotonic value.
method.doc: Returns the monotonic value. It throws std::exception if this fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time has no monotonic clock value (see fort::myrmidon::Time::HasMono).

method.name: Now
method.brief: Gets the current Time

method.name: operator<
method.brief: Less than operator

method.name: operator<=
method.brief: Less or equal operator

method.name: operator==
method.brief: Equal operator

method.name: operator>
method.brief: Greater than operator

method.name: operator>=
method.brief: Greate or equal operator

method.name: Parse
method.brief: Parses from RFC 3339 date string format.
method.doc: Parses from [RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) date string format, i.e. string of the form `1972-01-01T10:00:20.021-05:00`. It is merely a wrapper from google::protobuf::time_util functions.

method.name: Round
method.brief: Rounds a Time to a Duration
method.doc: Rounds the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to the halp-rounded up fort::myrmidon::Duration d. Currently only multiple of fort::myrmidon::Duration::Second and power of 10 of fort::myrmidon::Duration::Nanosecond which are smaller than a second are supported.

method.name: SortKey
method.brief: Returns the SortableKey representing this Time

method.name: SortKey
method.brief: Returns a SortableKey representing a Time pointer
method.doc: Returns a fort::myrmidon::Time::SortableKey representing a pointer to a fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time. Passing a nullptr to this function, will represent the smallest possible key possible, which is then mathematically equivalent to -âˆž fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time (no result of Time::Parse can represent this value).

method.name: Sub
method.brief: Computes time difference with another time

argument.name: t
argument.doc: the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time to substract to this one.

method.name: ToTimestamp
method.brief: Converts to a protobuf Timestamp message

method.name: ToTimestamp
method.brief: In-place conversion to a protobuf Timestamp

argument.name: timestamp
argument.doc: the timestamp to modify to represent the fort::myrmidon::Time::Time and fort::myrmidon::Time::Time

method.name: ToTimeT
method.brief: Converts to a `time_t`
method.doc: Converts to a `time_t`. Please note that time_t have a maximal resolution of a second.

method.name: ToTimeval
method.brief: Converts to a `struct timeval`
method.doc: Converts to a `struct timeval`. Please note that time_t have a maximal resolution of a microsecond.
